messages.message: Distance from center of source to face of detector. Number must be followed by units; valid units are: meters, m, cm, mm, km, feet, ft, ', in, inches, or ". You may also add multiple distances, such as '3ft 4in', or '3.6E-2 m 12 cm' which are equivalent to 40inches and 15.6cm respectively.

Shieldings are treated as shells with the innermost shell being the first one you add (the top one in this box), and the subsequent shieldings layered around that one. Any sources not attributed as components of shieldings are treated as point sources in the center.
Choose from a library of predefined common shielding materials.
Allows you to define and fit for atomic number and areal density.
Show the Chi of each peak for the current model on the chart, or the relative peak area multiple between current model and observed peak.

Checking this option will allow other nuclides being fit for, other that the one assigned to a peak, to contribute to the expected counts in a observed peak. This could for instance be useful when fitting for both Ho166m and U235 that both have a peak near 185 keV.
When checked attenuation due to air between the source, or outer shielding, and detector will be accounted for in the calculations.
This forces the isotopes of a element to all be the same age in the fit.
Isotopes of same element same age
Enforce isotopes for the same element should all have the same age.

Corrects for decay and in-growth effects that happen during the time the measurement is being taken. Resulting activities correspond to the start time of the measurement. May take take additional computation time to find solution.

Geometry to use for modeling "trace" sources, or self-attenuating sources.
By default, all sources are point sources at the specified distance from the detector, for all geometries.
However, if you make a nuclide a "trace" source (by clicking on a shielding's ⊕ button and selecting "Add Trace Source"), or a self-attenuating source (by selecting the Source for:" checkbox when a shielding has the same element as a nuclide you are fitting), then the source isotope will be modeled as distributed throughout the shielding, and ray-tracing will be used to account for different attenuations at each location within the shielding.
To keep things simple, choose "Point/Spherical" geometry unless you will perform a fit to a "trace" or self-attenuating source.
There are no background peaks defined, not subtracting them
There is no background spectrum loaded, so can not subtract background peak areas from foreground.

The background spectrum does not have any peaks identified. You should load the background spectrum as the foreground, identify the peaks to potentially be subtracted, and then switch back to your current foreground/background combination.
Updated shielding dimension to be a minimum thickness.
Shielding thicknesses have been scaled to be less then detector distance.
You can only fit for the atomic number of one generic shielding at a time.
An invalid chi2 was calculated for {1} keV, other results may be invalid
Error opening uploaded Source Shielding Fit Model: {1}
Error opening Source Shielding Fit Model from database: {1}
Unable to load selected model - sorry :(
Models Previously used with this foreground:
There are no models in the database for you
Nuclides are added or removed according to the photopeaks used for this fit, thus may not be edited in this table

Activity of the nuclide. Entering a reasonable starting value may help the fit, or the activity does not have to be fit for. Values may be entered in formats similar to '12.4 kBq', '1.0mCi', '55.3uCi', '15.82Mbq'

Age of the nuclide. Values may be entered in format similar to: '23.3s' '2 hl' - (hl stands for half lives), '5.23y', '23:14:21.343', '19min', etc. Note that nuclides that decay to stable children can not be aged.
Should the fit try to find the nuclide activity as well, or assume the entered value is correct?
Should the fit try to find the nuclide age as well, or just assume the entered value is correct? This option is not available for nuclides which decay to only stable children.
This is the mass of the bare nuclide assuming the activity listed.
This is the uncertainty in activity from the fit.
This is the uncertainty in age from the fit.
Nuclides children are stable so aging is not allowed because it doesn't effect gamma spectrum.

The Y-axis is the peak area counts, minus the expected number of counts from the currently displayed" " source and shielding values, all divided by the statistical uncertainty. The square of this" " is what is used to optimize the shielding and sources.

The Y-axis is the peak area counts, minus the expected number of counts from the currently displayed source and shielding values, all divided by the statistical uncertainty. The square of this is what is used to optimize the shielding and sources.
The Y-axis is the multiple of observed peak counts, relative to what would be expected from the current source and shielding values.
